plist.p: Good morning, London. Good afternoon to those of you in Hong Kong and in Mumbai. I'm delighted to report that 2011 was our ninth consecutive year of record income and profits. And this performance once again shows that we are in the right markets, with the right strategy, and have the right leadership in place to deliver consistent value for our shareholders.

Standard Chartered has continued to perform strongly with an 11% increase in profits. Despite our rights issue in 2010, we have delivered a return on equity of over 12%. And we enter 2012 in great shape, poised for further growth, with strong momentum in both of our businesses. Now in a moment, Richard will walk you through today's results in more detail and then Peter will talk about where we see opportunities to grow the business in the next few years.

But first, there are a number of things I'd like to highlight. As a board, we continue to keep shareholder interests top of mind when determining our strategy. In the last few years, our income – we have grown our income, profits, and earnings per share while simultaneously increasing our capital reserves and total dividends. Despite turbulence in the global markets and the increased cost of regulation, we have continued to generate considerable value for our shareholders year on year.

This year, we are again increasing the total amount of dividend paid to shareholders. The board is recommending a final dividend of $0.5125 per share, bringing the total annual dividend to $0.76 per share, which is up 10%.

I'm quite sure that there will be some of you at least here today who will be interested in our approach to remuneration. Put simply, our approach to remuneration has not changed. We continue to reward our people for sustained high performance. And we do not reward failure or short-term risk taking. Despite considerable growth in profits, the bonus pool has been kept flat and the amount we are paying out in bonuses is less than we are paying out to our shareholders by way of a dividend.

Let me also comment on the contribution we have made more broadly to society and the communities we serve. In the five years since 2006, we have increased our total lending by more than 90% with mortgage lending up 40%, and SME lending up 70%. We now employ nearly 87,000 people. It's worth noting that in achieving this, we have not taken a penny in direct government support anywhere in the Group.

So, in summary, 2011 was another year of strong performance for Standard Chartered. And the board remains confident for the year ahead. Despite continued global uncertainty and despite the ever-changing regulatory environment, the Bank is in great shape and we have again demonstrated the continued success of our strategy, our diverse footprint, our unique culture and values, and most especially, the quality of our people.
Let me now ask Richard to take you through the numbers. Richard?

Thank you, John. Good morning, London, and good afternoon to Hong Kong and Mumbai. What I'll be presenting to you today is another very good set of results. And we have delivered this despite the challenges in the external operating environment.

As you listen to this presentation, there are a number of recurring themes. Firstly, continued top-line growth and good momentum in both businesses. Secondly, the diversity of our performance be it by geography, by product or client segment, giving the Group real segment – giving the Group real resilience. And thirdly, our conservative operating model demonstrated by our capital, liquidity and funding strength, allowing us to remain open for business for our customers and our clients.

Let me draw out several key highlights. This is the ninth consecutive year of record income and profit with income over $17.6 billion and profit of almost $6.8 billion. We have delivered double-digit income growth, up 10%, including double-digit growth in Consumer Banking income and in Wholesale Banking client income.

Expenses are also up 10% despite the impact of the UK bank levy and a materially higher takeup on the early retirement program, or ERP, in Korea than we had expected. Our strong cost control has allowed us to continue to invest in both businesses.

We delivered neutral cost income jaws for 2011 on a reported basis. Excluding the impact of the UK bank levy, jaws were 2% positive, and excluding the ERP as well, jaws were 4% positive. Double-digit growth in both pre- and post-impairment profit up 10% and 11%, respectively.

Our balance sheet is in excellent shape, with an advances-to-deposit ratio of 76.4% and a liquid assets ratio of 27.5%. Continued capital strength with Core Tier 1 at 11.8% and total capital at 17.6%. This is an excellent all round performance, demonstrating the resilience of our business model and strategy.

Over the past nine years, income has grown at a compound annual growth rate of 16% and profit at 21%. Our balance sheet strength and the consistency of our performance have been recognized by the rating agencies. We are the only major international bank to have been upgraded by all three rating agencies since the start of the financial crisis and most recently by Standard & Poor's in December 2011.

When considering the 2011 performance, there are a number of areas where the final outcome is different from guidance given at the time of the pre-close in December. Firstly, we had a very strong December with Wholesale Banking performing particularly well and across all businesses despite difficult market conditions, thereby enabling the Group to deliver double-digit income growth.

Secondly, the takeup of the ERP in Korea was far stronger than we had expected. We had signaled the likely cost to be some mid to high tens of millions of dollars, whereas the final cost was $206 million, primarily in Consumer Banking, some $150 million higher than we had expected. As well as being a nonrecurring item, it is anticipated that this will deliver ongoing savings of some $95 million per annum, and, therefore, a $300 million positive delta to expenses in 2012.

Thirdly, the UK bank levy has settled at $165 million versus the $185 million guided. Fourthly, the loan impairment for the year is up 3% as opposed to our expectation of being below the level seen in 2010, and I will go into this in more detail later.
And finally, the effective tax rate was lower at 27.2% reflecting both changes in profit mix and increased utilization of foreign tax credits relating to branch profits.

Looking at the final performance for 2011. Income has grown 10% year-on-year. Net interest income is up 20%, reflecting continued growth in customer loans and customer deposits, up 9%, and 11%, respectively, and also an increase in our liability margins. Non-interest income is down 1%. Within this, Consumer Banking non-interest income was up 8%, driven by strong performances in wealth management and SME. Wholesale Banking non-interest income was down 5%, with the increase in transaction banking insufficient to offset a decline in corporate finance and financial markets.

We have maintained a firm grip on expenses, up 10%, while continuing to invest in both businesses to build the income engines of tomorrow. Loan impairment was up 3% reflecting our diversified portfolio, the economic performance to the markets we serve, our disciplined approach to risk management and in Consumer Banking, the benefit attached into the sale of a number loan portfolios.

Other impairment is higher at $111 million compared to $76 million predominantly due to higher charges against Indian exposures taken in the first half. Operating profit of $6.775 billion is up 11%. Underpinning this strong performance is the diversity of our business. Next slide.

The diversity of the Group whether by geography or by product is something we have consciously built out over the past decade or so. This diversity gives us real resilience and underpins the Group's stability to continue to grow even when some geographies had a difficult year. Our largest market, Hong Kong, contributed just 17% of the Group's income in 2011 even after an exceptionally strong performance.

A number of geographies delivered a strong performance in 2011 particularly markets where we prioritized investment in 2010 with Hong Kong, Singapore, China, Malaysia and Indonesia primary examples. This has allowed the Group to deliver record levels of income in a year when one of our largest geographies, India, saw income fall by 11%.

You can see on this slide a number of product areas and capabilities that we have invested in over recent years such as corporate finance, commodities, and within transaction banking and foreign exchange renminbi capabilities that have added diversity to the product mix.

Looking at performance metrics. This slide shows the key performance metrics both on a reported basis, which includes the UK bank levy and also excluding the levy. Excluding the impact of the levy, profit was up 13%, normalized EPS was up 4% to $2.05 in part reflecting the full dilutive impact of the rights issue completed in November 2010.

The current level of return on equity is impacted by the levels of capital the Group is now carrying to meet the emerging regulatory requirements and the continuing drag of a low interest rate environment on a deposit-rich bank. Return on equity was 12.2% on a reported basis and 12.6%, excluding the impact of the levy.

Turning to the balance sheet. The balance sheet remains conservative, well diversified, highly liquid, and strongly capitalized, a source of real competitive advantage. We remain open for business and in growth mode. The Group remains primarily deposit funded with total deposits up 12% year-on-year and 31% over the last two years despite increasing levels of competition for liquidity across a number of our markets.

Our advances-to-deposit ratio and liquid asset ratio both remained strong. Our A/D ratio was 76.4% and our liquid asset ratio increased to 27.5%. We continue to be a significant net lender to the interbank market and we have some $165 billion of liquid assets.
We also have minimal refinancing requirements over the next few years, only some $4 billion through to the end of 2013 and both our Wholesale Banking and Consumer Banking businesses are self-funded.
In terms of Basel III, we already meet the minimum requirement of 100% for both the net stable funding ratio and the liquidity coverage ratio well ahead of the required implementation date.

Turning to assets. Our customer loans and advances, which grew 9% in 2011, continue to be well-diversified by geography and by sector. Hong Kong remains our largest geography. However, this represents only 19% of customer loans and advances. We have a continuing bias to secured lending in Consumer Banking, with 83% of the book being either fully or partially secured. We have low loan-to-value ratios on our mortgage book with an average of 49%.

We have a short maturity profile on our Wholesale Banking loan book with 64% of the book under one year in tenure, reflecting the trade bias of our business. We have no direct sovereign exposure to Greece, Ireland, Italy, Portugal or Spain, our total direct exposure to entities domiciled in these countries remains low at around 0.5% of total assets. We've been actively managing our European exposures for the last two years.

Moving on to capital. The Group continues to maintain a very strong capital position, with a core Tier 1 ratio of 11.8%. We have generated $4.7 billion of profit attributable to ordinary shareholders. We continue to grow risk-weighted assets in both businesses, with Wholesale Banking up 12% and Consumer Banking up 7%. The majority of growth in risk-weighted assets has been driven by credit risk. In addition, market risk risk-weighted assets was up 35%, or some $6 billion, reflecting in the main, the introduction of Basel 2.5. Tier 1 is at 13.7%, and total capital is at 17.6%. We remain extremely well-capitalized, and are generating good levels of organic equity.

Throughout 2011, we have had good support from capital markets, raising almost $5 billion of lower Tier 2 and CDO funding. The support has continued into 2012, evidence in January by two successful transactions in the senior unsecured and lower Tier 2 capital space. Both were heavily oversubscribed, reflecting the strong demand in the market for our name.

Looking now at performance by business and Consumer Banking. The Consumer Banking business had a strong year in 2011 with record income up 12% to almost $6.8 billion. The business has benefited from selective growth in unsecured assets, improving deposit margins, and the impact of the investments made in 2010. Asset margins in the second half were up on the first half by a couple of basis points, generating positive momentum into 2012. Within this performance, we have seen good double-digit income growth across all of our high values segments with private banking up 21%, SME up 14% and priority banking up 10%.

Expenses increased 10% resulting in positive jaws, which ran to 1% as we maintained tight control on business-as-usual costs. We've continued to standardize processes and improve cost efficiency to increase our investment capacity. In 2011, we have continued to invest in our Consumer Banking franchise with head count up by over 1,200 staff focused on China, Singapore Hong Kong and Africa. Within this total, frontline head count was up nearly 1,000. We added 35 new branches in 2011, including 19 in China. In addition, we have refreshed or replaced more than 400 ATMs, we have enhanced our mobile and Internet banking capabilities and increased marketing spend year on year by some tens of millions of dollars.

You can see from the slide that expenses in the second half increased 18% or $387 million over the first half, reflecting, firstly, the non-recurrence of recoveries made against structured note provisions in the first half of $86 million. Secondly, a chafe of $189 million relating to the Consumer Banking share of the ERP charge in Korea, and, thirdly, increased investment spend in the second half by some tens of millions of dollars. The Consumer Banking loan impairment charge has decreased by 9% to $524 million, but increased in the second half of the year and I'll go into this in more detail later. As a result, Consumer Banking profit is up an excellent 26% to $1.65 billion.

Turning to products. Mortgage income was down 2% with margin compression of some 30 basis points and a 2% fall in balances primarily in Korea. Margins in our key markets were impacted by competition, regulation and the increased cost of liquidity. Market shares remained strong in our key mortgage geographies although we have given up some share as we have priced the book up across a number of markets, including Hong Kong, Korea, China, and India.

We're seeing good growth in deposits despite increased competition for liabilities across some of our key markets such as Hong Kong, Singapore, India and Taiwan. Deposit income is up 17% year on year benefiting from a 6% increase in balances and an improvement in margins of some seven basis points.

Wealth management delivered double digit income growth year on year with income up 12%. In the second half wealth management income has shown good resilience, but was down 6% on the first half impacted by weaker investor sentiment given the slowing global economy and market volatility. The outlook for wealth management remains very much influenced by any resolution to the European debt crisis.

Moving to the next slide. Income in credit cards and personal loans, or CCPLs, shows excellent momentum, up 18% year on year. Balances increased 17% over 2010, driven by selective asset growth in markets such as Hong Kong, Singapore, Malaysia and Korea and we continue to gain market share.

SME income is up 14% year on year driven mainly by cash management and foreign exchange. We have delivered 30% higher income per customer managed by a relationship manager across our top eight markets. The SME book remains deposit led, is predominantly secured, and we continue to maintain a strong vigilance on the credit quality of our loan book and we focus on building multi-product relationships.

Moving to impairment. Loan impairment is down both in terms of dollars and basis points of loss. Overall, Consumer Banking loan impairment was $524 million, 9% down on 2010. Loan impairment increased by some $102 million half-on-half reflecting four factors: the underlying growth of our book, mix change, a small portfolio impairment charge in the second half as opposed to a release in the first half, and a lower level of sales of written down portfolios in the second half.

Looking by product, you will see that loan-loss rates are down across all product categories. Included within other loans are CCPL balances of $19.1 billion, up 17% or $2.8 billion year on year. The improvement in loss rates resulted mainly from the improved portfolio performance in India and in the UAE, continued investment in collections infrastructure and the benefit from sales of written down portfolios.

We remain comfortable with our overall exposures and continue proactively to manage our book. However, in 2012, we expect loan impairment to increase, reflecting the size and the mix of the loan book as well as some lower levels of sales of written down portfolios. To summarize for Consumer Banking, overall, this is a strong set of results with good double-digit income growth. We have maintained a tight grip on expenses, but have continued to invest in order to underpin future income momentum.

Wholesale Banking. Wholesale Banking has delivered another strong performance in 2011 with income up 9% and client income up 10%, the ninth consecutive year of double-digit client income growth. Own account income was up 2% on 2010 levels. We continue to focus on deepening client relationships, with client income contributing 82% of total Wholesale Banking income.

In 2011, 48% of Wholesale Banking client income was generated offshore, up from 41% in 2010 and demonstrating the importance of the network and the increasing interconnectivity of our markets. Total Wholesale Banking income in the second half was broadly flat on the first half, reflecting the resilience of the business model even in a challenging period.

We have seen a number of repricing opportunities across our footprint in 2011 partially reflecting our dollar liquidity strength, but also some withdrawal of European competitors. For example, we have repriced corporate loans in Hong Kong, and there was evidence of repricing in debt capital markets across our core footprint. Cash margins have improved year on year, and trade margins, although down on 2010, increased marginally in the second half of the year.

Expenses rose 6% in 2011, but were broadly flat half on half, we've maintained a tight control on costs despite an acceleration of investment spend in the second half of the year. Investment in 2011 was mainly focused on technology and infrastructure, such as continued investment in our transaction banking platforms.

Wholesale Banking head count increased by some 600 staff during the year with new investment head count mainly in operations to support volume growth. Loan impairment in 2011 was up 26%, and other impairment was up 55%, and I'll go into more detail on this later.

Profit before tax increased 9% to reach a record $5.2 billion. This strong performance was delivered despite a challenging market environment, with high levels of uncertainty and volatility driven principally by that Eurozone crisis.

Looking at income in more detail. Income remains well-diversified with double-digit growth in the three largest businesses, transaction banking, financial markets and corporate finance. Commercial banking, by which I mean trade, cash management, lending and the associated foreign exchange, remains core to our clients' day-to-day business needs, and is at the heart of our Wholesale Banking business, contributing 55% of client income.

Lending income fell 3% to $841 million with margin compression more than offsetting an increase in average balances of 15%. In trade, income was up 9%, driven by 25% growth in average assets and contingents, as we continue to take market share. Trade margins fell 14 basis points year on year, but showed a slight increase in the second half, benefiting from repricing across a number of our markets. Cash management income saw excellent growth of 27% over 2010, underpinned both by strong growth in average balances, up 25%, and an improvement in cash margins of 11 basis points.

Global markets income increased 7%, with financial markets, the largest component, contributing 55% of total global markets income. I'll go into more detail on financial markets on the next slide. ALM income of $921 million is up 1%, with income in the second half up 14% on the first half, driven in particular by good income in China and in Korea.

Corporate finance income was up 10% after a very strong finish to 2011. The 2011 corporate finance story is one of diversity and sustainability of income. We closed 15% more transactions with a greater number of small- to mid-sized deals across multiple geographies, and over 50% of income is net interest income.

Principal finance income was down 34%, with the business impacted by difficult market conditions, which limited exit opportunities and put pressure on valuations. We continue to invest in this business, which has a good pipeline and strong returns.

Financial markets. Our financial markets business benefited from good volume growth as a result of its strong link to our transaction banking products set, giving it resilience despite difficult market conditions. Foreign exchange income was up 20%, driven by a 14% increase in slow foreign exchange volumes, and strong growth in our options business. Foreign exchange income has benefited from good growth in our transaction banking business and also from the internationalization of the renminbi.

The rates business was up 7%, impacted by the benign interest rate environment and margin pressure from local bank competition. Commodities and equities grew strongly with income up 47%. Commodities performed particularly well, reflecting increased product capability as well as our ability to assist our clients in managing volatility and commodity prices. Commodity volumes continue to grow strongly.

Capital markets income increased 1%. The business continues to win strategic transactions and ranks highly in the lead tables. Credit income was down 33% with transaction volumes impacted by difficult market conditions.

Moving to loan impairment. Wholesale Banking loan impairment was $384 million, up 26% on 2010, with the vast majority of this loan impairment charge relating to increased provisioning on previously impaired accounts. Other impairment has increased from $64 million to $99 million, predominantly because of higher charges against Indian exposures taken in the first half of the year. Early alerts have increased mainly due to accounts affected by ongoing investigations in India. We continue to monitor the situation, but do not expect to see material impairment resulting from these early alert accounts.

Gross non-performing loans in Wholesale Banking have decreased 11% since December 2010, mainly in the MESA region. Credit quality across the Wholesale Banking book remains strong. We remain watchful, but are not currently seeing any signs of stress. We continue to be disciplined and proactive in our approach to risk management. Our Wholesale Banking loan book is conservative, diverse, and predominantly short dated.

To summarize, Wholesale Banking has delivered another good set of results, with record levels of client income. There is currently good underlying business momentum building off the back of a strong close to 2011.

Turning to geographic performance, Peter will talk to you in more detail about Greater China, India, Singapore and Korea. However, let me highlight some of the other geographies. Within other APR, which grew income 12%, China, Indonesia and Malaysia all delivered double-digit growth. MESA income increased 2%, in part impacted by the geo-political events within the region. Within this, the UAE, which represents over 50% of MESA income, grew by 4%, and both Pakistan and Bangladesh grew income at a double-digit rate.

Africa's income growth of 8% was driven mainly by Wholesale Banking, which contributes over two-thirds of total income. Wholesale Banking client income grew 10%, with both transaction banking and financial markets performing very well in 2011, offsetting a decline in corporate finance. Consumer Banking income grew 11%, with good growth in credit cards and personal loans, as well as wealth management.

The Americas, UK and Europe region continues to originate and support our clients' cross-border business within our footprint of Asia, Africa and the Middle East. In 2011, income increased 16%, and profit by 58%, with strong performances in cash management, ALM, and commodities.

Turning then to outlook. We have started 2012 strongly off the back of a very strong finish to 2011. Looking at January and our momentum into February, Consumer Banking has had a good start with income ahead of the comparable period last year. Wholesale Banking has had a strong start with income well ahead. Expenses are under tight control across the Bank and credit quality remains good.

We continue to take a conservative approach to managing the balance sheet, maintaining a strong liquidity position and keeping a watchful eye on asset quality given the uncertainties in the external environment. We will maintain a tight grip on expenses whilst continuing to invest in growth. As you have come to expect, we will manage cost growth in line with income growth, so neutral jaws.

However, when thinking about our performance in 2012, it is important to bear in mind a number of factors: first of all, the material and increasing drag on both income and costs from an evermore complex set of regulatory requirements; secondly, the continued strength of the U.S. dollar against Asian currencies; and thirdly, we are not immune to potential turbulence in the global economy whether arising from the Eurozone or elsewhere.

So, we started the year with very good momentum and exceptionally strong balance sheet and a full transaction pipeline. We remain focused on the fundamentals of our business and on the disciplined execution of our strategy. We are well-positioned in some of the most exciting growth markets in the world and we are well placed to make the most of the opportunities they present.
Thank you. And now I'll hand over to Peter.

Thank you, Richard. Good morning to all of you and good afternoon to those of you in Hong Kong and India. As John and Richard have said, these results represent our ninth consecutive year of record income and profits. We are superbly placed in some of the world's fastest growing markets. We have the right strategy, a distinctive culture and values, a strong brand. We are focused on delivering for our shareholders, supporting our clients and customers, and making a positive impact on the communities in which we live and work.

But you shouldn't let the consistency of our performance mask the underlying achievement. Every year brings new challenges and 2011 was no exception. Two of our largest markets saw sharp falls in profits. Some of our business streams particularly in Wholesale Banking faced very difficult conditions. The increasing burden of regulation and the UK bank levy created significant headwinds. Yet, our 2011 performance demonstrates once again the power of our strategy and the resilience of our business model.

The crisis that began in 2007 and brought markets to a halt in the autumn of 2008 continues to unfold. The roots of the crisis are now laid bare, too much debt, too little growth, and erosion of competitiveness and massive macro imbalances. Restoring the vitality of the world's most developed economies is an enormous endeavor, with profound, social, and economic consequences.

Working through these problems will be painful and will take time. Governments are struggling to control borrowing without undermining growth and employment. Regulators are wrestling with how to make the banking system safer without triggering too much deleveraging. Central bankers are pumping money in, but in doing so, risk laying the seeds for the next crisis. Ugly turn to protectionism and populism are being heard everywhere.

Amidst all this, two facts are clear. One is that we are witnessing a profound shift in economic power and dynamism from the developed world to the emerging giants of the developing world. The second is that banks need to get out of the box of being part of the problem, and get into the mode of being part of the solution.

The crisis has undoubtedly accelerated the fundamental shifts in the world economy. Whilst not immune to the problems of the West, countries like China, India, Brazil and Indonesia continue to grow at pace, building industries and infrastructure, turning hundreds of millions of people into consumers. The clouds over the West should not obscure the sheer scale of wealth creation and social progress in the developing world.

Of course, such growth brings challenges: inflation, friction over resources, social inequality, environmental degradation. Moreover, the lack of consumption growth in the West undermines the export-driven model that has powered most Asian economies. But whilst we shouldn't underestimate such challenges, neither should we underestimate Asian countries' ability to respond. Intra-regional trade and investment is growing extremely rapidly, domestic consumption is growing fast, policy makers in Asia and particularly in China, have much more monetary, regulatory and fiscal flexibility than their counterparts in the West. Taken as a whole, emerging Asia should continue to grow at mid to high-single digit rates, slower than before the crisis, but still much faster than the West.

This sharp polarization in economic performance and prospects is one reason different banks are in such different positions. Some banks have little choice but to deleverage, downsize and retreat. Others, like us, have the liquidity, capital and business model to turn the turbulence to our advantage. But all of us face the challenge of the ongoing avalanche of regulation, none of us can be complacent about the continuing fragility of the system. We are supportive of Basel III, yet we worry about the increasing profusion of national or regional variations. This is creating incredible complexity, huge costs and a multitude of unintended consequences, not least, the fragmentation of the global financial system and the emergence of new forms of financial protectionism.

We also worry about the extent to which the regulatory agenda is driven through the rearview mirror. All the attention has been on avoiding another Lehmans or RBS. Very little of the Basel III agenda is relevant to the Eurozone crisis; even less has been done that might protect us from the longer-term consequences of QE, the LTRO, the extraordinary expansion of the role of central banks.

At Standard Chartered, our approach to all of this is straightforward, stand above the fray, stick to our strategy and proven business model, focus on our clients and customers, keep a tight grip on the basic disciplines of good banking. But it is easier to say than it is to execute. Whilst we are rarely the specific targets of regulatory changes, they do affect us, they do erode our economics. Regulatory drag was a headwind in 2011 and will be again in 2012.

Yet, for all the negatives, regulatory drags, slowing growth in Asia, the risk of political and economic stress in the Eurozone and the Middle East or elsewhere, we remain confident about our ability to grow and perform. Even as economic growth in our markets slows to more sustainable levels, we can win more market share. Our capital and funding strength allows us to be open for business while others are pulling down the shutters. We are taking share in core products, like trade finance, with volume growth of 25%.

We see huge opportunities in our core markets of Asia, Africa and the Middle East, both within the individual markets and in facilitating the explosive growth of trade and investment flows within the emerging world. And we also see huge opportunities in being the bridge for trade and investment between Europe and the Americas and Asia, Africa and the Middle East. Whether it's helping Unilever or Diageo make the most of the opportunities in Asia, or Tata invest in Jaguar Land Rover in the UK, or Volkswagen, Tesco, Caterpillar issue RMB bonds.

And it's by doing exactly this kind of thing, lending to clients, facilitating their trade, helping them manage FX and commodity price risk, identifying and supporting new partnerships and investments, helping them to access capital markets, that we are fulfilling our social purpose, helping drive economic growth, helping create jobs.

At Standard Chartered, we've never lost sight of the role we play, of the impact we can have on the broader economy. In the five years since 2006, we've increased our lending by 91%, from large multinationals to SMEs, from credit cards to mortgages. Our profits have increased by 113% in the same period.

Despite all that's changing around us, don't expect big changes in strategy. We still want to be the world's best international bank, leading the way in Asia, Africa and the Middle East. We build deep, longstanding relationships with our clients and customers, we're focused on organic growth, investing at pace in both our businesses. We're obsessed with the basics of banking, being strongly capitalized and highly liquid, managing risk proactively, keeping tight control of costs, staying well diversified.

Underpinning our strategy is a distinctive culture and set of values. Standard Chartered is here for good. Here for good in the sense of commitment and permanence, here for good in the sense of always seeking to do the right thing. But whilst the fundamentals of our strategy won't change, we will be constantly anticipating and adapting to the opportunities and challenges we see. Regulatory change will force us to do some things differently and will change the economics of some of our businesses, but our mindset is as much about how we turn such changes to our advantage as it is about mitigating the impact.

So far, I've talked big picture stuff, the macro environment, regulation, our strategy. Now I want to change gear and talk about some specific markets. And rather than start with the success stories, let me start with some of the places in which we've faced challenges.

Korea, as you know, we've not been satisfied with our performance in Korea. The cost income ratio has been too high and the return on capital too low. The core issue was labor productivity. We couldn't reward strong performance nor deal with poor performance. Pay was driven more by seniority than merit. Sustained efforts to get the union to agree to a more flexible approach had failed, so, in 2011, we took a more direct approach. This sparked a strike which lasted 10 weeks and then collapsed. We stayed open throughout the strike, a testament to the professionalism and commitment to our customers of many of our staff. And while it had some impact on income momentum of the order of $50 million, overall, income remained resilient, and customer deposits grew during 2011.

In December, we launched an early retirement program. This had a big impact on Korea's profits in 2011, but it was undoubtedly the right thing to do. This program will deliver annualized savings of $95 million, and coupled with enhancement of performance management, will enable a big shift in the culture, making Korea much more like the rest of the Bank.

To further underscore our commitment to Korea, in January, we rebranded the Bank, dropping the SC First Bank name that harks back to the acquisition of Korea First Bank and replacing it with Standard Chartered. Korea is now a seamless part of Standard Chartered as a whole.

There's still lots to do before we really have Korea performing the way we want given the scale of the opportunities in the market. But we have taken significant steps in the right direction. We've just begun on the new lunar year. It's the year of the black dragon, auspicious for change and prosperity. So with a more productive platform, a business with momentum and the dragon in our favor, we enter 2012 with confidence.

India was the second of our big markets to see a decline in profits in 2011. However, unlike in Korea, this followed a spectacular year. As you will recall, in 2010, India was our most profitable market. That 2011 proved challenging didn't surprise us at all. To tackle inflation, the Reserve Bank of India hiked interest rates 13 times in two years. This had a predictable impact on economic growth down from 8.5% in 2010 to 7% in 2011 and on business confidence. In addition, a combination of protracted political and corporate governance issues further sapped business confidence, resulting in many investment projects being delayed or canceled.

Whilst this correction was very real, and the slowdown in regulatory reforms and vital infrastructure projects will have lasting consequences, we remain confident about the longer-term growth prospects of India. The underlying drivers of growth – urbanization, demographics, better education and an extraordinarily dynamic and entrepreneurial business culture remain robust. Indeed, there are already some signs that the climate is changing, clear signals of an end to the rate cycle, some steps on critical reforms, progress on transparency issues.

Moreover, looking only at the onshore income understates the strength of our India franchise. Whilst onshore Wholesale Banking income fell by 14%, income from Indian clients elsewhere in the network more than doubled largely offsetting this decline as we leverage our network to support our Indian clients' international objectives;

So our enthusiasm for India as a market remains undiminished. We continue to invest apace in people, products, technology and branches. We remain convinced that India will become one of the world's largest economies and is one of our biggest growth opportunities.

For example, Greater China. Taken together, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Mainland China delivered income of $4.4 billion and profits of $2.1 billion, up 18% and 46%, respectively. Greater China thus represents 25% of the Group's total income and 31% of total profits.

In Taiwan, profits were up 44% to $342 million helped in part by recoveries on structured notes. Our business in Greater China is increasingly focused as much on the flows between these markets as on the opportunities within them. We led the development of the dim-sum bond market and priced and launched 56 such bond issues last year.

But Greater China isn't the only region in which we have seen strong performance in 2011. Across the ASEAN countries of Southeast Asia, we delivered income of $4.2 billion and profits of $1.9 billion, up 21% and 32%, respectively.

Singapore is now the third of our markets to have delivered more than $1 billion of profit following Hong Kong, which hit the mark for the first time in 2007 and India, which did so in 2009. Our Africa business continues to grow well with income up 8% or 13% on a constant currency basis. Meanwhile, in Pakistan, income was up 13% and in Bangladesh, 16%.

Delivering record income and profits in any year is always a good result. On behalf of the board, I'd like to take this opportunity to thank them once again for their hard work in making this happen.

Amidst all this turmoil, we remain committed to our performance aspirations. Our markets are robust and resilient. We have the right strategy and we're sticking to it. We have a powerful brand, a distinctive culture and some fantastic people. Our client and customer franchise is stronger than it has ever been.

2012 will undoubtedly bring new and unexpected challenges. The global recovery is fragile. There are many risks and uncertainties. We expect volatility and turbulence.
